The [[Baloch people|Baloch]] are an [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] people of the [[Western Iranian]] group and [[Northwestern Iranian|Northwestern]] subgroup that mainly lives in three countries: [[Pakistan]], [[Iran]] and [[Afghanistan]]. More specifically they live in Southwestern [[Pakistan]] (most in the province of [[Balochistan]], but also in [[Sindh]]), Southeastern [[Iran]] (most in the province of [[Sistan and Balochistan]], but also in eastern [[Hormozgan]] and eastern areas of [[South Khorasan]] and [[Razavi Khorasan]] provinces) and Far Southern [[Afghanistan]] (most in the southern areas of the provinces of [[Nimruz Province|Nimruz]], [[Helmand Province|Helmand]] and [[Kandahar Province|Kandahar]], but also in the western areas of [[Farah Province|Farah]] and [[Herat Province|Herat]] provinces). There are also scattered and significant Baloch communities in other countries like [[Turkmenistan]]. There is a [[Baloch diaspora]] in [[India]], [[Oman]] [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[United Arab Emirates]] ([[UAE]]).

| total = 10,000 | region1 = {{flag|Uzbekistan}} | pop1 = 5,000 | ref1 = | region2 = {{flag|Tajikistan}} | pop2 = 4,000 | ref2 = | region3 = {{flag|Kyrgyzstan}} | pop3 = | ref3 = | region4 = {{flag|Russia}} | pop4 = 486 | ref4 = <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perepis2002.ru/ct/doc/TOM_04_01.xls |format=XLS |title=НАЦИОНАЛЬНЫЙ СОСТАВ НАСЕЛЕНИЯ |website=Perepis2002.ru |accessdate=2016-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229073920/http://www.perepis2002.ru/ct/doc/TOM_04_01.xls |archivedate=2016-02-29 |df= }}</ref>
| genealogy = | regions = <!-- for e.g. a list of regions (countries), especially if regionN etc below not used -->
| languages = [[Tajik language]] | philosophies = | religions = [[Sunni Islam]] | related_groups = | footnotes = }} {{Romani people}} '''Lyuli''' ({{lang-ru|Люли}}) or Jughi is an ethnic group of [[Romani people|Romani]] living in [[Central Asia]], primarily [[Tajikistan]], [[Uzbekistan]] and [[Kyrgyzstan]]. They speak a Tajik dialect. The Lyuli practice [[Islam]]. They have a clan organization (the Lyuli word for ‘clan’ is ''tupar'', the Jughi word - ''avlod''). Division into sub-clans is also practiced. The Lyuli [[community]] is extremely closed towards non-Lyuli.<ref name=besson>{{ru icon}} [http://zigane.pp.ru/Pressa2_4.htm Николай Бессонов. Цыгане и пресса. Эпопея о люли] - Some photos of Lyulis</ref>
Traditional occupations: crafts, including jewelry, cattle trading, [[mendicancy]] and music.
== Etymology == There are several names for the Lyuli: Jughi, Multani or Luli. However, they refer to themselves as ''Mugat'' or ''Mughat'' ({{lang-fa|مغان}}, derived from Old Persian ''[[magi]]'', "fire-worshipper"), as well as ''Ghurbat'' ({{lang-ar|غربات}}), which means "lonely". The term ''Multani'' signifies a person who originates from the city of [[Multan]] (in modern-day Pakistan), because some of the Lyuli emigrated from Multan around 1380 AD.
According to Professor Khol Nazarov, the ancestors of the Lyuli belonged to a caste of singers, musicians and dancers. Faced with hardship in their homeland, they were forced to leave and disperse.
==Lyuli in Kyrgyzstan== The Lyuli live in the south of [[Kyrgyzstan]], in [[Osh Region]]. Their [[Standard of living|living standard]] is extremely low due to discrimination. Many children are not educated in their [[First language|mother tongue]] and many Lyuli have no official documents. Lyuli society is working towards improvement of their living standards and preservation of their culture.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.ca-oasis.info/oasis/?jrn=32&id=245 Интернет-Журнал "Оазис" Народ без прав]</ref>
==Lyuli in Russia== Starting from the early 1990s, the Lyuli began [[Urbanization|migrating]] into [[Russia]]n cities, most noticeably around [[Train station|railway stations]] and [[Market (place)|market]]s. At first, [[Russians]] mistakenly identified them as [[Civil War in Tajikistan|Tajik refugees]] or ethnic [[Uzbeks]] due to their traditional Central Asian robes. [[Russian Roma]] emphasize that the Lyuli are distinct from them, however they are considered to be a subgroup of the [[Romani people|Romani]].<ref name=besson/> They are a frequent target of Russian [[White power skinhead|far right skinheads]].<ref name="NZ_Herald_10008515">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/2/story.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10008515 |title=Russia's far-right on rise |author=Osborne, Andrew |date=29 January 2005 |agency=[[The Independent]] |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=15 October 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.goacom.org/overseas-digest/ImAsy&Race%20(EU)/Cases04/russia04.htm Russia 2004] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015060926/http://www.goacom.org/overseas-digest/ImAsy%26Race%20%28EU%29/Cases04/russia04.htm |date=October 15, 2006 }}</ref>
==Lyuli in Uzbekistan== There are approximately 12,000 Lyuli in Uzbekistan.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nationalgeographic.org/projects/out-of-eden-walk/articles/2017-01-trading-tresses/ |publisher=''[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'' |quote=There are about 12,000 Mugats in Uzbekistan. Uzbeks refer to them, often with contempt, as Lyuli or Gypsies, though there is scant genetic evidence linking them to the world’s Roma diaspora. The group divides itself into a caste system that suggests a migration from the Indian subcontinent into Central Asia centuries ago. Traditionally the Mugat were wandering musicians and entertainers. Today they live in tight-knit neighborhoods that are considered no-go zones by other Uzbeks. They are one of the world’s marginal peoples. Many survive by begging, or by recycling scrap metal or plastic bottles. |title=Trading in Tresses |date=January 17, 2017 |first=Paul |last=Salopek |access-date=January 18, 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox Sculpture | image = Memoria Urbana Belin Juan Garaizabal. Night.jpg | title = Memoria Urbana Berlin | artist = [[Juan Garaizabal]] | year = 2012 | type = Square section [[Hollow structural section|steel tube]] and [[Light-emitting diode|LED illumination]] system | height_imperial = 101 | imperial_unit = ft | metric_unit = m | city = [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] | museum = Bethlehemkirchplatz (Bethlehem Square) }} '''''Memoria Urbana Berlin''''' (also known as [[Reconstruction (architecture)|Reconstruction]] Bohemian Bethlehem Church) is a [[Public art|public sculpture]] by [[Spanish art]]ist [[Juan Garaizabal]] that stands in the middle of the Bethlehemkirchplatz, [[Mitte]] district, [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]. It was constructed in June 2012 on the [[mosaic]] marking the exact site and size of the original Bohemian or Bethlehem Church ({{lang-de|Böhmische Kirche, Bethlehemskirche}}), which was destroyed in the war.<ref>[http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2013/06/18/actualidad/1371567587_938428.html ElPais.com]</ref> The [[sculpture]] is made up of 800 [[Metre|meters]] (2,600 [[Foot (unit)|feet]]) of square section (12x12 cm/4.7 in) [[Hollow structural section|steel tube]] and 300 meters (984 feet) of [[Light-emitting diode|LED illumination]] system. Its [[Structural art|structure]] draws in the air the lines of the [[silhouette]] of the lost construction, recreating its [[volume]] in the form of a [[sketch (drawing)|sketch.]] It measures 25 x 15 x 31 metres (82 x 49 x 101 feet) in height and weighs 44 [[short ton]]s (40 [[Ton|metric tons]]).<ref>[http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/videos/telediario/escultor-espanol-juan-garai-zabal-presenta-proyecto-memorias-urbanas/1451945/ RTVE Garazaibal presents the ''Memorias Urbanas'' project (video)]</ref>
==Construction and maintenance== Originally planned as a [[Installation art|temporary installation]], as of December 2013 the district and [[Local government|municipal authorities]] have decreed permanent status for the work.<ref>[http://www.morgenpost.de/bezirke/mitte/article122562359/Skulptur-der-Bethlehemskirche-bleibt-nach-Protesten.html Morgenpost.de]</ref> Administrative proceedings for the permanent allocation on [[public land|public grounds]] are currently ongoing. The Lux-Bethlehem e.V. cultural trust, representing twenty of the public and private institutions that promoted the permanent installation, has been formally created to guarantee the [[Property maintenance|maintenance]] of the [[Monumental sculpture|sculpture]].
==Symbolism== [[File:Berlin, Bethlehems-Kirche (Rekonstruktion Memoria Urbana 2012), Kuppel erleuchtet..jpg|thumb|Berlin, Bethlehems-Kirche (Rekonstruktion Memoria Urbana 2012), illuminated cupola]] {{unsourced section|date=April 2018}}
It is a monument dedicated to [[Freedom of thought|freedom of conscience]] and to [[immigration]] with the spirit of [[Europeanism]].
The original Bohemian Church otherwise Bethlehem Church was built between 1733 and 1735 in the middle of the [[Friedrichstadt (Berlin)|Friedrichstadt]] (now the Mitte district) of Berlin, representing one of the most positive chapters of relations between [[Germany]] and [[Bohemia]]. Thanks to King [[Frederick William I of Prussia]], [[Czechs|Czech]] [[refugee]]s leaving their homeland for religious reasons were admitted to the Friedrichstadt district of Berlin. It was a monument to the [[Toleration|tolerance]] pervading the foundation of the [[Prussia|Prussian State]].
In 1943, it was badly damaged by bombing. Later, in 1963, the church was demolished and the site incorporated into the facilities of [[Checkpoint Charlie]].

{{lang|ar|شركة مبادلة للاستثمار}} | logo = [[Image:Mubadala_Logo.jpg|250px]] | type = [[Joint stock company]] ([[Government owned corporation|Government owned]]) | foundation = January 2017 | location_city = [[Abu Dhabi]] | location_country = [[United Arab Emirates]] | location = | locations = | key_people = [[Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed|HH Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], Chairman
[[Khaldoon Khalifa Al Mubarak]], CEO and Managing Director | area_served = | industry = [[Investment|Diversified Investments]] | products = | services = | revenue = {{increase}} [[United Arab Emirates dirham|AED]] 165.6 billion (2017){{Cite web|url=https://www.mubadala.com/en/news/mubadala-investment-company-announces-full-year-2017-financial-and-operational-highlights|title=Mubadala Investment Company Announces Full Year 2017 Financial and Operational Highlights|date=April 29, 2018|publisher=Mubadala Investment Company}} | operating_income = {{increase}} [[United Arab Emirates dirham|AED]] 10.7 billion (2017) | net_income = | assets = {{increase}} [[United Arab Emirates dirham|AED]] 369.4 billion (2017)) | equity = {{increase}} [[United Arab Emirates dirham|AED]] 258 billion (2017) | num_employees = 700 (2011) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = [[Piaggio Aerospace]] | slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.mubadala.com}} | dissolved = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Mubadala Investment Company PJSC''' ({{lang-ar|شركة مبادلة للاستثمار}}) (Mubadala) is a state-owned holding company that can be characterized as a [[sovereign wealth fund]]. It was established in January 2017 as a Public Joint Stock Company, merging the Mubadala Development Company and the [[International Petroleum Investment Company]], and is a wholly owned investment vehicle of the government of [[Abu Dhabi]], in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. Mubadala’s mandate is to facilitate the diversification of Abu Dhabi’s economy. Its focus is on managing long-term, capital-investments intended to deliver strong financial returns and tangible social benefits for the emirate.{{cite web|url=http://mubadala.ae/about/history/ |title=The Mubadala Story | Mubadala Development Company | Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates |publisher=Mubadala.ae |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mubadala.com/en/who-we-are/senior-executive-management/ |title=Senior Executive Management |publisher=Mubadala |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}}{{cite web|url=http://www.arabaviation.com/ |title=Aviation News | Airline Profiles | Jobs & Aircraft Listings |publisher=Arabaviation.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-05}} The company owns '''Advanced Technology Investment Company''' (ATIC), a high tech investment company and owner of [[GlobalFoundries]], the world’s second largest semiconductor foundry company by revenue.[http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/technology/atic-chip-producer-takes-big-steps-in-us "The National"], accessed October 28, 2013. ==Advanced Technology Investment Company== {{ infobox company | name = Advanced Technology Investment Company (ATIC) | logo = | successor = | foundation = {{start date|2008}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Abu Dhabi]] | location_country = [[UAE]] | key_people = [[Ibrahim Ajami]] (CEO) | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.atic.ae}} | footnotes = }} '''Advanced Technology Investment Company''' (ATIC) is an investment company in the [[high-technology]] sector,[http://www.atic.ae/about-atic/ "About Us"], ''ATIC, accessed June 12, 2011. owned by ''Mubadala Development Company'', a wholly owned investment vehicle of the government of [[Abu Dhabi]], in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. ATIC wholly owns [[GlobalFoundries]], the world’s second largest semiconductor foundry company by revenue. It also works to build what they describe as a technology ecosystem in Abu Dhabi, funding over AED 100 million in local R&D activities and supporting educational initiatives that have thus far reached over 1,000 UAE Nationals.[http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/technology/abu-dhabi-eyes-growth-through-innovation "The National"], accessed October 28, 2013.[http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/economics/investing-in-emirati-talent-to-build-a-knowledge-economy "The National"], accessed October 28, 2013. ===History and growth=== ATIC was established in 2008. Through a joint venture, ATIC and [[Advanced Micro Devices]] (AMD) created the world's third largest independent [[foundry]] [[GlobalFoundries]] in early 2009.[http://www.atic.ae/leadership/Ibrahim-Ajami/1 "Leadership"], ATIC, accessed June 12, 2011. In late 2009, ATIC acquired [[Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing]] of Singapore, the world's second largest dedicated independent [[semiconductor foundry]].[http://www.atic.ae/media-center/archive/November2009/10 “Press Release”], ATIC, accessed June 14, 2011.[http://www.atic.ae/in-the-news/2009-09-07-Financial-Times-Abu-Dhabi-to-Take-on-Taiwans-Chipmakers.pdf “Abu Dhabi to take on Taiwan’s Chipmakers”], Financial Times, accessed June 14, 2011. In January 2010, the two operations were integrated, and have since functioned as one company under the GlobalFoundries brand.[http://www.atic.ae/media-center/archive/January2010/12 Press Release], ATIC, accessed Juned 14, 2011. In August 2010, the firm joined with other investors to fund Texas-based [[Calxeda]], a start-up company for producing [[ARM architecture]]-based computers for the server market.[http://news.cnet.com/8301-13924_3-20013683-64.html “Green chip start-up gets $48 million in funding”], CNET, accessed June 14, 2011. It "worked with the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] to develop a masters program in microelectronics at the [[Masdar Institute of Science and Technology]] in Abu Dhabi."[http://allitwares.com/market-news-body-Abu-Dhabi-High-tech-mecca-or-mirage-459.html “Abu Dhabi: High-tech mecca or mirage?”], AllItWares, accessed June 14, 2011.[http://www.masdar.ac.ae/FastFacts.html “Masdar Institute – Fast Facts”], Masdar Institute, accessed June 14, 2011. Also in 2010, the firm joined a research partnership with the [[Semiconductor Research Corporation]] (SRC) to conduct research in the Abu Dhabi region.[http://www.nanowerk.com/news/newsid=18960.php "Semiconductor Research Corporation and Advanced Technology Investment Company Chart Course for Semiconductor Research in Abu Dhabi"], ''Nanowerk'', November 11th, 2010, accessed June 12, 2011. In 2011, it announced investments of $5.5 billion to expand chip manufacturing in Singapore, Dresden, Germany, and Saratoga County in the U.S. state of New York.[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-18/abu-dhabi-s-atic-investing-in-chip-plant-sees-acquisitions-1-.html "Abu Dhabi’s ATIC Investing in Chip Plant, Sees Acquisitions"], “Bloomberg”, May 18, 2011, accessed June 12, 2011.[http://arabnews.com/lifestyle/science_technology/article450749.ece “A future built on silicon”], “Arab News”, accessed June 14, 2011. It also announced a $6–$8 billion computer chip factory in Abu Dhabi for completion in 2012.[http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/atic-to-raise-globalfoundries-stake “ATIC to raise Globalfoundries stake”], “The National”, accessed June 14, 2011. In June 2016, they announced that they would unite and become one with their sister company [[International Petroleum Investment Company]].{{cite web|title=Fast FT|url=https://next.ft.com/content/03f7ac73-aedc-36f0-934d-b54e64cc13af|website=next.ft.com|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=29 June 2016}}{{cite web|last1=French|first1=David|last2=Tolba|first2=Ahmed|last3=Aboudi|first3=Sam|title=Abu Dhabi government orders merging of Mubadala And IPIC - state news agency|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/emirates-ma-mubadala-ipic-uae-idUSD5N17U015|website=Reuters|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=29 June 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kerr|first1=Simeon|title=Abu Dhabi to merge sovereign wealth funds Ipic and Mubadala|url=https://next.ft.com/content/99337866-3dcf-11e6-8716-a4a71e8140b0|accessdate=7 July 2016|language=English|date=29 June 2016}} In November 2018, Mubadala lead a new $60 million investment round in [[logistics]] software [[Startup company|startup]] Turvo.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/abu-dhabi-state-fund-leads-60-million-funding-in-logistics-software-startup-1541674801|title=Abu Dhabi State Fund Leads $60 Million Funding in Logistics Software Startup|last=Phillips|first=Erica E.|work=WSJ|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}} ===Research and development=== ATIC has invested more than Dh100 million in research grants and funds since 2009 for building a globally-competitive technology R&D ecosystem within Abu Dhabi. It partners with the Semiconductor Research Corporation, a leading university-research consortium, to drive local research towards minimum energy electronic systems.[http://www.thenational.ae/thenationalconversation/comment/energy-is-the-key-to-technology-but-where-will-we-find-it "The National"], accessed October 28, 2013. It is supporting research initiatives spanning Khalifa University, UAE University, American University of Sharjah, Masdar Institute and New York University Abu Dhabi. In May 2013, ATIC and the Semiconductor Research Corporation (SRC) launched the ATIC-SRC Centre of Excellence for Energy Efficient Electronic Systems (ACE4S), to be hosted jointly in Abu Dhabi by Khalifa University of Science, Technology and Research, and Masdar Institute of Science and Technology.[http://www.thenational.ae/business/industry-insights/technology/atic-launches-centre-of-excellence "The National"], accessed October 28, 2013. ATIC is investing Dh17.5 million in the project, an amount matched by Masdar Institute and Khalifa University. The total budget for the center is Dh35m spread during the initial three-year phase. The center will focus on research in four key areas: energy harvesting, power management, sensor technologies and wireless communications networks. ATIC and the state of German state of Saxony have invested $4.8 million in twinned laboratories that research 3-D stacking of integrated circuits. The project consists of one lab hosted at the Masdar Institute of Science and Technology in Abu Dhabi and the other based at the Technische Universität Dresden.[http://www.itp.net/588634-atic-and-saxony-to-open-twin-semiconductor-labs#.Uhr3wRumgnE "ITP"], accessed October 28, 2013. The labs, which host 10-12 graduate and PhD students, focus on research around three-dimensional chip stacking, a potentially faster and more energy efficient semiconductor technology.[http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1266549 "EE Times"], accessed October 28, 2013. ===Human capital=== To prepare for the development of a high-tech cluster and a Global Foundries manufacturing facility in Abu Dhabi, ATIC and other local entities have developed education programs, ranging from primary and secondary school education to vocational training and graduate studies. These programs have reached over 1,000 Emiratis to date.[http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/arabic/article.cfm?articleid=2910 "Wharton UPenn"], accessed October 28, 2013. ===Senior management=== [[Ibrahim Ajami]] is the Chief Executive Officer. He oversaw the joint venture between ATIC and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) of the creation of Global Foundries.[http://www.atic.ae/leadership/Ibrahim-Ajami/1 “Leadership”], “ATIC”, accessed June 14, 2011. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.mubadala.com/ Mubadala Development Company] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110629135234/http://www.atic.ae/ ATIC official website] [[Category:Companies based in Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:Financial services companies established in 2017]] [[Category:Companies of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Government-owned companies]] [[Category:Government-owned companies of Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:Investment companies of the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Sovereign wealth funds]] [[Category:2017 establishments in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:2017 establishments in Abu Dhabi]]

'''Mugheri''' (or '''Mughery''', '''Mughairi''', {{lang-ar|المغیری}}) are a social group descended from Arabs, however, in [[Pakistan]] they are considered to be [[Baloch people|Baloch]]. As per research, Mugheri are descended from an Arab Field Marshal called [[Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim]], who was appointed as a Field Marshal for [[Sindh]] by his elder brother and famous [[Governor]] of [[Sindh]] during [[Abbasid Caliphate]] named [[Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim]].<ref name="The History of India As told by its own historians the Muhammadian Period Vol-1">{{cite book | title=History of India | publisher=Cambridge | author=Henry Miers Elliot | authorlink=History of India | year=1867 | location=Cambridge,Delhi | pages=543, 544}}</ref> Daud was appointed as a Governor of Sindh in 800AD (184 [[Hijri]]) by [[Harun al-Rashid|Caliph Haroon-ur-Rashid]] (786-809). Governor Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim governed Sindh for the longest period of nine years and later his son Bashar Bin Daud Bin Hatim became the next successor Governor of Sindh during the caliphate of Mamoon-ur-Rashid. Additionally, the Mughera tribe was at the climax because they ran their business, trade, affairs and matters effectively and were considered as wealthy tribe under the [[Abbasid Caliphate]].
== History ==
=== Researchers and scholars === [[File:Turbat in Bhag.jpg|thumb|Bhag, Baluchistan; This is possible second place after Iraq where Mughera's tribe settled in majority]]
==== Khair Mohammad Burriro ==== According to this researcher <ref name="Encyclopedia of Castes ">{{cite book | title=Encyclopedia of Castes| publisher=Sindhi Language Authority,Hyderabad,Sindh| author=Khair Mohammad Burriro | authorlink=Encyclopedia of Castes | year=2010 | location=Hydearbad,Sindh| pages=6000}}</ref> Mugheri are directly descended from [[Mir Ali Khan]], the second son of [[Mir Jalal Khan]] who is believed to be an ancestor of [[Baloch people|Baloch]]. The researcher further mentions in his book that, in a [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi]] tribe, there was a Hajija Family, which had Mugher Khan and Buland Khan as two brothers. Moreover, Mugheri tribe is descended from Mugher Khan who had three sons Rozi, Khushal and Hassan Mugheri while Rozi had four sons namely Nazar, Feroz, Jaghir and Dighar.<ref>The Encyclopedia of Castes(in Sindhi)By Khair Mohammad Burriro Page no: 1520,1521</ref>
==== Ayaz Bhagat ==== A well known Researcher on Castes living in Sindh [[Pakistan]] found that <ref name="The castes,tribes & nations living in sindh ">{{cite book | title=The castes,tribes & nations living in sindh| publisher=Sindhi adabi board,hyderabad,sindh| author=Ayaz Hussain Bhagat | authorlink=The castes,tribes & nations living in sindh | year=2012 | location=Hydearbad,Sindh| pages=822–824}}</ref> Mugheri are not [[Baloch people|Baloch]] because, Rai bahadur Lala Hetoram, who was a local person and the first historian of Baluchistan did not include Mugheri in any of Baloch tribes. Further, this indicated that, Mugheri do not belong to any Baloch tribe. Ayaz further says that Mugheri are descended from [[Arab]] [[Warrior]] Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim, who came in Sindh in 800AD along his delegation.<ref>The Castes, Tribes and nations living in Sind (in Sindhi) By Ayaz Bhaghat pages 822,823,824</ref>
==== Mansel Longworth Dames ==== The scholar of oriental and Portuguese languages and researcher on Baloch races, an English officer [[Mansel Longworth Dames]] (1850–1922) in his book ''The Baloch Races'' did not mention the Mugheri in the [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi tribe]]. Although, he considered it as 17th sub-caste of Magsi tribe.<ref name="Dames1904">{{cite book|author=Mansel Longworth Dames|title=The Baloch Race: A Historical and Ethnological Sketch|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D1ebTdUEcKIC|accessdate=8 June 2013|year=1904|publisher=Royal Asiatic society|page=75}}</ref>
==== Shaikh Sadik Ali Ansari ==== Ansari writes in his book ''The Musalamn Races'' that [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi]] (Buledi) tribe is descendant of Mir Ali the second son of [[Mir Jalal Khan]]. Mir Ali had two sons Zendi Khan and Murad Khan, while Zendi had two sons Sundar and Haji. All Burdi (Buledi) are descendant of Sundar and Haji Khan or in other words Burdi are descendant of Zendi Khan. He further added that Mugheri are descendant of Haji Khan (Hajija) or in other words they are said to be sub-caste of Burdi tribe.<ref name="ʻAlī1901">{{cite book|author=Anṡārī ʻAlī Sher ʻAlī|title=A short sketch, historical and traditional, of the Musalman races found in Sind, Baluchistan and Afghanistan, their genealogical sub-division and septs, together with an ethnological and ethnographical account|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eQk8AAAAMAAJ|accessdate=8 June 2013|year=1901|publisher=Printed at the Commissioner's press|page=24}}</ref>
==== Rai Bahadur Lala Hetoram ==== The first historian of Baluchistan [[Lala Hoat Ram]] of 1907 in his book “History of Baluchistan” did not consider and mention Mugheri in any Baloch tribes and even <ref>History of Baluchistan By Rai Bahadur Hetoram 1907</ref> he did not consider Mugheri as sub-caste of Magsi and [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
==== Justice(R) Khuda Bux Marri ==== The research work of [[Mansel Longworth Dames]] and his combined English poetry was translated in Sindhi by Justice(R) Khuda Bux Marri, who wrote a book “Baluchistan in the constitution of History” in the last of this book <ref>Baluchistan in the constitution of history By Justice Retired Khuda Bakhsh Marri page: 261</ref> he made an index of Baloch tribes in which he did not mention Mugheri in [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi]] (Buledi) tribe but he considered them as sub-caste of Magsi.
==== M. K. Pikolin ==== He was an English Researcher and Scholar who also considered Mugheri as sub-caste of Magsi in his book on baloch races. On the basis of research work of the above Scholars and researchers, it has been clear that Mugheri are not Baloch that is why Lala Hoatu Ram did not mention them in any Baloch tribe. While, Shaikh Sadik Ali Ansari on unknown basis considered them, in [[Burdi (tribe)|Burdi]] (Buledi) tribe. [[Mansel Longworth Dames]], M.K Pikolin and Justice(R) Khuda Bux Marri considered Mugheri as sub-caste of Magsi which is actually a Sindhi tribe. These later Scholars even did not explain anything that when Mugheri became part of the Magsi. On the basis of combined research of various researchers and scholars, it can be concluded that Mugheri are not Baloch.
=== Origin === After the review of various above research, it has concluded{{Who|date=October 2017}} that Mugheri are not clan of Baloch or [[Rajput]] or [[Soomra (tribe)|Soomra]] or [[Kalhoro]] or [[Channa]] or [[Bhatti]] or Machi or Muhani or Jat but Mugheri are in fact an [[Arab]] and they are descended from great Field Marshal Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim. Thus descendants of Mughera call themselves as Mugheri (i.e.; Descendant of Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim). In addition, the Caliph Haroon-ur-Rashid, who remained famous caliph in Abbasid Caliphate. In his caliphate Sindhi tribes were fighting for their freedom and Arab tribes who were inhabitants of Sindh such as Yemeni and Hejazi were great opponents of each other. For controlling the critical situations of Sindh in 184 Hijri (800AD) Caliph Haroon-ur-Rashid appointed Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim as a Governor of Sindh.<ref name="The castes,tribes & nations living in sindh "/>
=== Arrival of Mughera in Sindh === <ref name="The History of India As told by its own historians the Muhammadian Period Vol-1"/> The Governor Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim before going to Sindh, appointed his brother Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim as Nawab (Naib) or Field Marshal and sent him with the delegation to Sindh for controlling the critical situations of Sindh. Since, the conditions of Sindh were critical, one side there was a war of detention of Sindhi people and on other side two [[Arab]] tribes were opponents of each other. When Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim reached [[Mansura (Brahmanabad)|Mansura]] the doors of the city were closed by Nazadya tribe and they made one condition for Mughera that he wouldn't take revenge from nazadya so ultimately they would leave the city.
=== The death of Mughera === According to the book" History of Yaqoubi" <ref>The History of Yaqoubi By Sindhi lekhak page 41</ref> when Mughera entered in the city, there was a huge crowd of nazadya tribe who started fighting with Mughera and killed him in that war. Though in other books of history, it is found that when Mughera reached the [[Mansura (Brahmanabad)|Mansura]] he got defeat from Nazadya tribe, and eventually, he ran and got shelter in mountainous area. Later, who told whole story to his brother Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim, who later came to Sindh and controlled the situations. However, before his arrival in Sindh Mughera was killed. Governor Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim remained ruler of Sindh for the period of nine years. The [[Arab]] warriors and tribes who came along Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim to Sindh, they ascribed their names with him after his death as Mugheri.
=== Rule of Mughera’s tribe === According to Scholar and writer Qazi Athar Mubarkapori that<ref name="Abbasid Caliphate and Subcontinent ">{{cite book | title=Abbasid Caliphate and Subcontinent| publisher=Baluchistan| author=Qazi Athar Mubarkapori | authorlink=Abbasid Caliphate and Subcontinent | year=1907 | location=Baluchistan,Pakistan| pages=1500}}</ref> Daud Bin Zaid Bin Hatim, brother of Mughera remained ruler of Sindh for the period of nine years and later his son Bashar Bin Daud Bin Hatim became the next successor Governor of Sindh during Mamoon-ur-Rasheed caliphate. They settled their many people, who then became the inhabitants of Sindh. As Mughera Bin Zaid Bin Hatim was killed in Sindh thus the people his tribe affiliated their names with Mughera. Who later, moved to Northern Sindh and called themselves with their Leader’s name as “Mugheri”.
=== Climax of Mugheri tribe === Qazi Athar Mubarkapori in his book “Abbasid Caliphate and Hindustan” writes that<ref name="Abbasid Caliphate and Subcontinent "/> in Abbasid Caliphate Mughera’s tribe was at the climax because they ran their business, affairs and matters in a great way and from this tribe most of the people were considered as riches in the Abbasid Caliphate. As compared to other Islamic countries, in Sindh Mughera’s tribe was a rich, remained rulers and later their population converted into the majority. Thus Governors of Mughera’s tribe contributed a lot for their tribe and they played vital role in the development of Sindh.<ref>The Abbasid Caliphate and Subcontinent By Athar Mubarkapori page: 1251</ref>
=== Settlement of Mugheri tribe === Mugheri indeed is an Arab race which is still found in the majority of these countries: [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Saudi Arab]], [[Oman]], [[Jordan]], [[Iraq]], [[Tanzania]], [[Egypt]] etc., while in [[Pakistan]] the huge population of Mugheri tribe lives in [[Baluchistan]], [[Sindh]] and [[Punjab, Pakistan]]. The major areas occupied by Mugheri tribe are; [[Bhag]], District [[Bolan District|Bolan]], [[Baluchistan]], [[Jacobabad]], [[Larkana]], [[Qamber Shahdadkot District]], [[Warah]], [[Warah|Waggan]], [[Nasirabad District]], [[Mehar, Pakistan|Mehar]], [[Dadu District]], [[Warah|La lu Rawnk]], [[Khairpur District]], [[Sanghar District]], [[Nawabshah]], [[Karachi]], and lower [[Punjab, Pakistan]] <ref>{{cite journal|author=Engineer Mir Iqbal Ahmed Mugheri|title=Mugheri: A Short Historical and Ethnological Sketch in Urdu|url=http://mugheri.webs.com/MUGHERI-TAREEKHI-TAZKRA-URDU.pdf |accessdate= 10 October 2013|year=2012|publisher=Mugheri Website Publishers|page=01}}</ref>
== Sub-castes == <ref name="The castes,tribes & nations living in sindh "/> The sub-castes of this tribe in [[Pakistan]] are: {{refbegin|colwidth=20em}} * Bhand (according to Balochi dictionary it means stubborn, tricky and meanie) * Aarbani (derived from Arban Khan) * Jaamra (derived from Jaam Khan) * Notkani (derived from Noat Khan) * Hajija (derived from Haji Khan) * Pahore * Sathiyani (derived from Sathi Khan) * Ferozani (derived from Feroz Khan) * Kalani (derived from Kaalan Khan) * Sirajani (derived from Siraj Khan) * Bambrani * Latifani (derived from Latif ) * Digarani (derived from Digaar) * Rehanzai * Madozai * Wahdadani (derived from Wahadad) * Khor * Rustamani (derived from Rustam Khan) * Nazrani (derived from Nazar) * Kherani (derived from Kher) * Somarani (derived from Soomar) * Rolyani * Jaghirani (derived from Jhagir) * Nariwal (derived from Bhag Nari,area in Baluchistan) * Fazulzai ( Fazal of Bhag Nari)
{{refend}}

The '''Muthuvan''’ people were loyal subjects of the dynasty of Madurai, according to tribal legend. When the dynasty was deposed, the surviving royal members migrated to [[Travancore]], central [[Kerala]]. On their way to Kerala, the Muthuvas carried the idols of [[Madurai]] [[Meenakshi]], the deity of the royal family, on their backs. The word Muthuvar in tamil is used to denote the same community in Tamilnadu. The word “Muthu” means elder and literal meaning of “Muthuvar” is elders. Muthuvan are the ancient tribes of this land.
The Muthuvans are very independent and reluctant to interact with the outside world. The Muthuva tribe grows [[Finger millet|ragi]], [[cardamom]] and [[lemon grass]]. Now they are also cultivating banana and tapioca for their daily usage. Most of their women are illiterate and strongly bonded with their customs.<ref>[http://www.tahrfoundation.org/html/mudu.htm Nilgiri Tahr Foundation, "''Muduvans''" retrieved 4/17/2007]</ref>

{{short description|16th-century political rebellion in Germany}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2007}} [[Image:Muenster Lamberti Koerbe 6428.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Cages of the leaders of the Münster Rebellion at the steeple of St. Lambert's Church]]
The '''Münster rebellion''' was an attempt by radical [[Anabaptist]]s to establish a [[communism|communal]] sectarian government in the German city of [[Münster]]. The city was under Anabaptist rule from February 1534, when the city hall was seized and [[Bernhard Knipperdolling]] installed as mayor, until its fall in June 1535. It was [[Melchior Hoffman]], who initiated [[adult baptism]] in [[Strasbourg]] in 1530, and his line of [[eschatology|eschatological]] Anabaptism, that helped lay the foundations for the events of 1534–1535 in Münster.
==Rebellion== [[Image:MuensterHinrichtungTaeufer.jpg|thumb|200px|Historical drawing of the execution of the leaders of the rebellion. In the background the cages are already in place at the old steeple of St. Lambert's church.]] After the [[German Peasants' War]] (1524–1525), a forceful attempt to establish theocracy was made at Münster, in [[Westphalia]] (1532–1535). Here the group had gained considerable influence, through the adhesion of [[Bernhard Rothmann]], the [[Lutheran]] pastor, and several prominent citizens; and the leaders, [[Jan Matthys]] (also spelled Matthijs, Mathijsz, Matthyssen, Mathyszoon), a baker from [[Haarlem]], and [[John of Leiden|Jan Bockelson]] (or Beukelszoon), a tailor from [[Leiden]]. [[Bernhard Rothmann]] was a tireless and vitriolic opponent of Catholicism and a writer of pamphlets that were published by his ally and wealthy wool merchant [[Bernhard Knipperdolling]]. The pamphlets at first denounced Catholicism from a radical Lutheran perspective, but soon started to proclaim that the [[Bible]] called for the absolute equality of man in all matters including the distribution of wealth. The pamphlets, which were distributed throughout northern Germany, successfully called upon the poor of the region to join the citizens of [[Münster]] to share the wealth of the town and benefit spiritually from being the elect of Heaven.
With so many adherents in the town, at the elections for the magistracy, Rothmann and his allies had little difficulty in obtaining possession of the town, and placing Bernhard Knipperdolling as the mayor after deposing the mainly Lutheran magistrates, who, until then, had seen him as an ally in their own distrust of, and dislike for, Catholics. Matthys was a follower of Melchior Hoffman, who, after Hoffman's imprisonment at Strasbourg, obtained a considerable following in the [[Low Countries]], including Bockelson, who became known as [[John of Leiden]]. John of Leiden and Gerrit Boekbinder<ref>{{cite book|title=A Companion to Anabaptism and Spiritualism, 1521–1700|editor1-first=John|editor1-last=Roth|editor2-first=James|editor2-last=Stayer|publisher=Koninklijke Brill NV|location=Leiden, The Netherlands|year=2007|page=222|first=Ralf|last=Klötzer|chapter=Chapter 6: The Melchoirites and Münster|isbn=978-90-04-15402-5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sYi50ItImHAC&lpg=PA222&pg=PA222#v=onepage&f=false}}</ref> had visited Münster, and returned with a report that Bernhard Rothmann was there teaching doctrines similar to their own. Matthys identified Münster as the "[[New Jerusalem]]", and on January 5, 1534, a number of his disciples entered the city and introduced adult baptism. Rothmann apparently accepted "''re''baptism" that day, and well over 1000 adults were soon baptised. Vigorous preparations were made, not only to hold what had been gained, but to spread their beliefs to other areas. The many Lutherans who left were outnumbered by the arriving Anabaptists, there was an orgy of [[iconoclasm]] in cathedrals and monasteries, and rebaptism became compulsory. The property of the emigrants was shared out with the poor and soon a proclamation was issued that all property was to be held in common.{{sfn|Cohn|1970|pp=262-4}}
==Siege== The city was then besieged by [[Franz von Waldeck]], its expelled [[bishop]]. In April 1534 on [[Easter Sunday]], Matthys, who had prophesied God's judgment to come on the wicked on that day, made a sally forth with only twelve followers, believing that he was a second [[Gideon]], and was cut off with his entire band. He was killed, his head severed and placed on a pole for all in the city to see, and his genitals nailed to the city gate.
The 25-year-old John of Leiden was subsequently recognized as Matthys' religious and political successor, justifying his authority and actions by the receipt of visions from heaven. His authority grew, eventually proclaiming himself to be the successor of [[David]] and adopting royal regalia, honors and absolute power in the new "[[Zion]]". There were at least three times as many women of marriageable age as men now in the town and he legalized [[polygamy]] and himself took sixteen wives. (John is said to have beheaded [[Elisabeth Wandscherer|one woman]] in the marketplace for refusing to marry him; this act might have been falsely attributed to him after his death.) Meanwhile, most of the residents of Münster were starving as a result of the year-long siege.
After lengthy resistance, the city was taken by the besiegers on June 24, 1535 and John of Leiden and several other prominent Anabaptist leaders were captured and imprisoned. In January 1536 John of Leiden, Bernhard Knipperdolling and one more prominent follower, [[Bernhard Krechting]], were tortured and executed in the marketplace of Münster. Their bodies were exhibited in cages, which hung from the steeple of [[St Lambert's Church, Münster|St. Lambert's Church]]. The bones were removed later, but the cages hang there still.
==Aftermath== The Münster Rebellion was a turning point for the Anabaptist movement. It never again had the opportunity of assuming [[politics|political]] importance, as both Catholic and Lutheran civil powers adopted stringent measures to counter this. It is difficult to trace the subsequent history of the group as a religious body, through changes in the names used and beliefs held.
The [[Batenburgers]] under Jan van Batenburg preserved the violent [[millennialism|millennialist]] stream of Anabaptism seen at Münster. They were polygamous and believed force was justified against anyone not in their sect. Their movement went underground after the suppression of the Münster Rebellion, with members posing as Catholics or Lutherans as necessary. Some [[Nonresistance|nonresistant]] Anabaptists found leaders in [[Menno Simons]] and the brothers [[Obbe Philips|Obbe]] and [[Dirk Philips]], Dutch Anabaptist leaders who repudiated the distinctive doctrines of the Münster Anabaptists. This group eventually became known as the [[Mennonites]] after Simons. They rejected any use of violence and preached a faith based on love of enemy and compassion.
In August 1536 the leaders of Anabaptist groups influenced by Melchior Hoffman met in [[Bocholt, Germany|Bocholt]] in an attempt to maintain unity. The meeting included followers of Batenburg, survivors of Münster, [[David Joris]] and his sympathisers, and the nonresistant Anabaptists.<ref>(Williams, p. 582)</ref> At this meeting the major areas of dispute between the sects were polygamous marriage and the use of force against non-believers. Joris proposed compromise by declaring the time had not yet come to fight against the authorities, and that it would be unwise to kill any non-Anabaptists. The gathered Anabaptists agreed to the compromise of no more force,<ref>(Williams, p. 583)</ref> but the meeting did not prevent the fragmentation of Anabaptism.

'''Naikpikhel''' (also '''Nekbikhel''' {{lang-ps| نیکپی خیل'}}) is a sub clan of Yousafzai Pashtun in Swat residing in the surrounding area of Tehsil [[Kabal, Swat]] lying just opposite to [[Mingora]] (Mingawara) on the western bank of [[River Swat]], [[Swat District|Swat]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]].
==Ethnicity==
''Naikpikhel'' belongs to '''Yousafzai''' branch of Pashtuns and further expanded to the family tree from ''Malak Yousaf (Yousafzai) '' to ''Aku (Aku Zai). From the first wife of ''Aku (Aku Zai) namely 'Gouhara', we have four sons which form the tree to four sub tribes as 1. ''Baizai'', 2. ''Khwaja Zai'', 3. ''Aba Zai'', 4. ''Khadak Zai''.
'''Khwaja Zai''' is expended to ''Mali Zai'', ''Sujni'', ''Shami Zai'', ''Naikpi Khel'', ''Shamo Zai'', ''Aden Zai''.
==Etymology== The name is a [[portmanteau]] of ''Nikpi'' (نیکپی), which is Pashto for "fortunate", and ''khel'' (خیل), which is Pashto for "tribe" or "clan".
==Naikpi Khel Sub Khel (Tribe/Clan)==
The Nikpikhel are divided into Four Sub clans, Aba Khel, Aisha Khel, Sheikh Sena and Musa. The Aisha khel comprises villages named Kanju, Dherai, Damghar, Kuza Bandai, Momdherai, Sigram, Lalu Bandai, Kamar Bandai, Jut Kot, Maloka, [[Bara Bandai]], Ghorijo, Dhelay, Jalawan and Ningolai.
'''Aba Khel''' is divided into ''Bar'' ("upper") Aba Khel and ''Koz'' ("lower") Aba Khel. Koz Aba Khel includes Dedahara, Gadi, Dagay, Kotlai, Akhud Kilay, Kabal, Sirsinai, Hazara, Aligrama and Malooch. Bar Aba Khel includes Kalakalay, Totano Bandai, Manja, Golden, Devlai, Nasrat, Shahdeari, Samai, Maira, Tall, [Dardyal],kamkhwalai, chur, penawrhai and Kamyari.
Bar Aba Khel is divided into three clans or tribes: Mata Khel, Zaina Khel, and Sahib Khel.
''Mata Khel'' sub clan are [[Karam Ali Khel (Karmali Khel)]], [[Maryam Khel]], [[Saran Khel]], [[Jora Khel]], [[Khusal Khel]], [[Bemi Khel]], [[Ranjo Khel]] and some descendant from wasli [[Khattak]] reside in Shahderai, Totano Bandai (Totanobandai), Golden, Manja and Dardyal.
''Zaina Khel'' sub clan are Merwais Khel, Usman Khel; Merwais Khel is further expanded to Sheda Khel, Umer Khel, Painda Khel, Musa Khel. Usman Khel is further divided into Jogi Khel, Nemat Khel, Baba Khel and Hasan Ali Khel.
''Sahib Khel'' is further divided into sub khel's like Mamo Khel (Mamo Khel sub Khel are Bado Khel, Mansaf Khel, Wali Khel), Bostan Khel, Baro Khel (Baro Khel sub khel is Ayoub Khel) , Dolat Khan Khel and Shabor Khel which are based in Devlai, Golden, Nasrat, Shalhand, Tagma, Malakana and Sirsinai. The grave of Baro baba famous as (Zyara Baba) is situated in Sirsinai.
'''Musa''' has only two sub khel according to Shajara namely Sar Abdal and Bakhti.
'''Aisha Khel''' is divided in three sub clans Zubar Khel, Khudai Khel and Dado Khel. ''Zubar Khel'' has further family tree of Rama Khel, Nemat Khel, Khata Khel and Pai Khel. ''Khudai Khel'' to Babokar Khel, Umer Khan, Zaal Khel and Mian Khan Khel. ''Dado Khel'' to Ali Khan Khel, Aibo Khel, Manki Khel, Jogi Khel, Ghali khel and Nasar Khel. In the same manner Ali Khan Khel is further expended to Audal Khel, Bucha Khel, Bara Khan Khel, Saido Khel and Sultan Khel. While Nasar Khel has sub khel of Shado Khel, Ajo Khel, Tawas Khel and Mandar.
'''Sheikh Sena''' has no such further sub khel information.

{{Oriental Orthodox sidebar|expanded=figures}} The '''Nine Saints''' were a group of [[missionary|missionaries]] who were important in the initial growth of [[Christianity]] in what is now [[Ethiopia]] during the late 5th century. Their names were Abba Aftse, Abba Alef, [[Abuna Aregawi|Abba Aragawi]], [[Abba Garima]] (Isaac, or Yeshaq), Abba Guba, Abba Liqanos, [[Abba Pantelewon]], Abba Sehma, and [[Abba Yem’ata]]. Although frequently described as coming from [[Syria]], only two or three actually came from that province; according to Paul B. Henze, others have been traced to [[Constantinople]], [[Anatolia]], and even [[Rome]].Paul B. Henze, ''Layers of Time: A History of Ethiopia'' (New York: Palgrave, 2000) p. 38. __NOTOC__ The Ethiopian historian [[Tadesse Tamrat]] speculates that they may have been connected with the anti-[[Monophysite]] and anti-[[Miaphysitism|Miaphysite]] persecutions that followed the [[Council of Chalcedon]], which adopted [[Chalcedonian|Dyophysitism]]. Tradition states that upon arrival they were welcomed by the [[Axum]]ite king [[Ella Amida]]. Their activities spread Christianity beyond "a narrow corridor between [[Adulis]] and Aksum along the caravan routes."Taddesse Tamrat, ''Church and State in Ethiopia, 1270-1527'' (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1972 {{ISBN|0-19-821671-8}}), p. 23. Besides converting the local inhabitants to Christianity, they also founded a number of [[monasticism|monastic]] houses that followed the rule of Saint [[Pachomius]]: Abba Aftse founded the monastery at [[Yeha]]; Abba Alef the northernmost establishment at [[Bi'isa]] on the south bank of the [[Mareb River]]; the foundation of the important monastery of [[Debre Damo]] is attributed to Abba Aragawi; Abbas Liqanos and Pantelewon are credited with establishing [[Pentalewon Monastery]] in [[Axum]]; Abba Garima founded [[Abba Garima Monastery]] north of [[Adwa]]; Abba Guba the one at Madara; Abba Sehma one at Sedenya; and Abba Yem’ata founded the southernmost one of the group in the [[Gar'alta]], noted for its [[Abuna Yemata Guh]] church named after him.This list is from [[Richard Pankhurst (academic)|Richard Pankhurst]], ''The Ethiopians, A history'' (Oxford: Blackwell, 2001), p.37 n. 38 [[File:Nine_Saints.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Icon of the Nine Saints, at Abba Pentalewon Monastery near [[Axum]], [[Ethiopia]].]] ==Abba Garima and the Garima Gospels== Recent radiocarbon dating supports the tradition of Saint Abba Garima's arrival at the Abba Garima Monastery in 494.{{cite web|url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Discovery-of-earliest-illuminated-manuscript%20%20/20990|title=Discovery of earliest illuminated manuscript|author=Martin Bailey|date=|work=|publisher=|accessdate=}} {{cite web|url=http://ethiopianheritagefund.org/artsNewspaper.html|title=?|author=|date=June 2010|work=|publisher=|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501030359/http://ethiopianheritagefund.org/artsNewspaper.html|archivedate=2012-05-01|df=}} The [[Garima Gospels]], which Garima is said to have written, is now regarded as "the world's earliest illustrated Christian manuscript" and the oldest surviving Ethiopian manuscript of any kind. == Nine Saints in Cyprus == A painting belonging to the Cyprus Presidential Palace with the same title (but quite unrelated to the above) was on exhibition in the Λεβέντειος Πινακοθήκη in Nicosia in 2014. Information about the painting is found in the August 25th issue of the Greek-Cypriot Sunday newspaper Καθημερινή, [http://www.kathimerini.com.cy/index.php?pageaction=kat&modid=1&artid=181626].
The nine saints are also found in the Sinaxaristis (Συναξαριστής in Greek), [http://www.saint.gr/2181/saint.aspx] == See also == * [[Thirteen Assyrian Fathers]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.dacb.org/stories/ethiopia/pantalewon_.html Life of Abba Pantelewon from ''The Dictionary of Ethiopian Biography''] {{Ethiopian saints by feast day}} [[Category:Cultural lists|9 Nine Saints]] [[Category:Ethiopian saints]] [[Category:History of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Syrian Christian saints]] [[Category:5th-century Christian saints]]

{{flag|Singapore}} |langs = [[Loncong language]], [[Malay language]] |rels = [[Islam]], [[Animism]] |related = [[Orang Kuala]], [[Orang Seletar]], [[Sama-Bajau]], [[Moken]], [[Urak Lawoi’ people]] }} [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Een vrouw van Orang-Laoet afkomst uit Solok Djambi Zuid-Sumatra TMnr 10005472.jpg|thumb|An Orang Laut woman in [[Solok]], [[Jambi]] southern [[Sumatra]]]] The '''Orang Laut''' are an [[ethnic group]] living around [[Singapore]], [[peninsular Malaysia]] and the [[Riau Islands]]. It also may refer to any Malay origin people living on coastal islands, including those of [[Andaman Sea]] islands of [[India]] and those in [[Thailand]] and [[Burma]], commonly known as [[Moken]]. ==Etymology== The [[Malay language|Malay]] term ''orang laut'' literally means "sea peoples". The Orang laut live and travel in their boats on the sea.{{cite journal|title=Cross Currents of Culture in Indonesia|author=Adriaan J. Barnouw|journal=The Far Eastern Quarterly|volume=5|issue=2|pages=143–151|date=February 1946|doi=10.2307/2049739|publisher=The Far Eastern Quarterly, Vol. 5, No. 2|jstor=2049739}} Another Malay term for them, ''Orang Selat'' (literally "[[Strait of Malacca|Straits]] people" ), was brought into European languages as ''Celates''. ==Distribution== [[File:Sea Nomads distribution map.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Regions inhabited by peoples usually known as "Sea Nomads".{{cite journal|author=David E. Sopher|year=1965|title=The Sea Nomads: A Study Based on the Literature of the Maritime Boat People of Southeast Asia|journal=Memoirs of the National Museum|volume=5|pages=389–403|doi=10.2307/2051635 }}
{{Legend|#e8bb9c|Orang Laut}}{{Legend|#86adfd|[[Moken]]}}{{Legend|#88c885|[[Sama-Bajau]]}}]] Broadly speaking, the term encompasses the numerous tribes and groups inhabiting the islands and estuaries in the [[Riau-Lingga Archipelagos]], the [[Pulau Tujuh Islands]], the [[Batam]] Archipelago, and the coasts and offshore islands of eastern Sumatra, southern Malaysia Peninsula and Singapore.[http://www.bartelby.net/67/837.html "The Malay Peninsula and Archipelago 1511–1722" ''The Encyclopedia of World History'' 2001]; ==History== [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Woonschuiten van de Orang-Laoets langs de kusten van Djambi en Riouw varende TMnr 10010489.jpg|thumb|House barges of the Orang Laut off the coast of [[Jambi]] and [[Riau]], [[Dutch East Indies]], circa 1914-1921.]] Historically, the ''orang laut'' played major roles in [[Srivijaya]], the [[Sultanate of Malacca]], and the [[Sultanate of Johor]]. They patrolled the adjacent sea areas, repelling real pirates, directing traders to their employers' ports and maintaining those ports' dominance in the area.Mary Somers Heidhues. ''Southeast Asia: A Concise History''. London: Hudson and Thames, 2000. Page 27 The earliest description of ''orang laut'' may have been by the 14th century Chinese traveller [[Wang Dayuan]] who described the inhabitants of [[temasek]] (present day Singapore) in his work ''[[Daoyi Zhilüe]]''.{{cite book|author=Paul Wheatley|authorlink=w:Paul Wheatley (geographer)|title=The Golden Khersonese: Studies in the Historical Geography of the Malay Peninsula before A.D. 1500|location=Kuala Lumpur|publisher=[[w:University of Malaya|University of Malaya Press]]|year=1961|oclc=504030596|pages= 82–83}} ==Popular culture== [[Image:RIAU WEB.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Villages of Orang Laut in [[Riau Islands]].]] In the story "''The Disturber of Traffic''" by [[Rudyard Kipling]], a character called Fenwick misrenders the Orang laut as "Orange-Lord" and the narrator character corrects him that they are the "Orang-Laut". ==See also== {{Portal|Indonesia|Malaysia|Singapore}} *[[Piracy in the Strait of Malacca]] *[[Malays in Singapore#The Orang Laut (Sea Nomads)|Orang Laut in Singapore]] *[[Urak Lawoi’ people]] ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.thingsasian.com/goto_article/article.1709.html Pirates of the East] * [http://www.unesco.org/courier/1998_08/uk/dossier/txt38.htm Where the spirits roam] * [http://www.iias.nl/iiasn/iiasn7/southeas/riau.html Riau in Transition] {{Commons category|Orang Laut}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Ethnic groups in Malaysia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Orang Laut}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sumatra]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malaysia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Singapore]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Malay descent| ]] [[Category:Modern nomads]] {{Indonesia-stub}} {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Infobox language |name=Ossetian |nativename={{lang|os|ирон ӕвзаг}} (''iron ævzag'') | pronunciation = {{IPA-os|iˈɾon ævˈzaɡ|}}, {{IPA-os|digoˈɾon ævˈzaɡ|}} |states= [[Russia]] ([[North Ossetia-Alania]]), [[South Ossetia]] ([[International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia|partially recognized]]), [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Turkey]] |ethnicity=[[Ossetians]] |speakers=ca. 570,000 |date=2001 – 2010 census |ref=e18 |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Indo-Iranian languages|Indo-Iranian]] |fam3=[[Iranian languages|Iranian]] |fam4=[[Eastern Iranian languages|Eastern]]? |fam5=Northern{{sfn|Windfuhr|2013|p=}} |ancestor=[[Scythian languages|Scythian]] |ancestor2=[[Alanian]] |dia1=[[Digor dialect|Digor]] |dia2=[[Iron dialect|Iron]] |dia3=[[Jassic dialect|Jassic]] |script=[[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] (Ossetian alphabet)

*{{flag|North Ossetia-Alania}} {{flag|Georgia}} *{{flagicon|South Ossetia}} [[Provisional Administrative Entity of South Ossetia]] {{flag|South Ossetia}} |iso1=os |iso2=oss |iso3=oss |lingua=58-ABB-a |map=Oseta latina skribo.jpg |mapcaption=Ossetian text from a book published in 1935. Part of an alphabetic list of proverbs. Latin script. |notice=IPA |glotto=osse1243 |glottorefname=Ossetian }} [[File:Caucasus-ethnic en.svg|thumb|right|290px|Ethnolinguistic groups in the Caucasus region]] '''Ossetian''' ({{IPAc-en|lang|ɒ|ˈ|s|ɛ|t|i|ə|n}}, {{IPAc-en|ɒ|ˈ|s|iː|ʃ|ə|n}}),{{sfn|OED:Ossetian||p=}} also known as '''Ossete''' and '''Ossetic'''{{sfn|Dalby|1998}} ({{Lang-os|ирон æвзаг|links=no|iron ævzag}}), is an [[Eastern Iranian languages|Eastern Iranian language]] spoken in [[Ossetia]], a region on the northern slopes of the [[Caucasus Mountains]]. It is a relative and possibly a descendant of the extinct [[Scythian languages|Scythian]], [[Sarmatians|Sarmatian]], and [[Alans|Alanic]] languages.{{cite book |last=Lubotsky |first=Alexander |title=Van Sanskriet tot Spijkerschrift Breinbrekers uit alle talen |publisher=Amsterdam University Press |location=Amsterdam |year=2010 |page=34 |isbn=9089641793 }} The Ossete area in [[Russia]] is known as [[North Ossetia-Alania]], while the area south of the border is referred to as [[South Ossetia]], recognised by Russia, [[Nicaragua]], [[Venezuela]] and [[Nauru]] as an independent state but by most of the rest of the international community as part of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. Ossetian speakers number about 577,450, with 451,000 speakers in the Russian Federation recorded in the 2010 census.{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/oss |title= Ossetic |work=[[Ethnologue]] |accessdate=2 February 2015}} ==History and classification== Ossetian is the spoken and literary language of the [[Ossetes]], a people living in the central part of the Caucasus and constituting the basic population of the republic of North Ossetia–Alania, which belongs to the [[Russia|Russian Federation]], and of [[South Ossetia]], which is ''de facto'' independent (but is ''de jure'' part of the [[Georgia (country)|Georgian Republic]] according to most other states). Ossetian belongs to the [[Iranian languages|Iranian]] group of the [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] family of languages (as hinted by its endonym, ирон). Within Iranian it is placed in an [[Eastern Iranian languages|Eastern]] subgroup and further to a Northeastern sub-subgroup, but these are [[Sprachbund|areal]] rather than genetic groups. The other Eastern Iranian languages such as [[Pashto language|Pashto]] and [[Yaghnobi language|Yaghnobi]] show certain commonalities but also deep-reaching divergences from Ossetic. From deep [[classical antiquity|Antiquity]] (since the 7th–8th centuries BCE), the languages of the Iranian group were distributed in a vast territory including present-day [[Iran]] ([[Persia]]), [[Central Asia]], [[Eastern Europe]] and the [[Caucasus]]. Ossetian is the sole survivor of the branch of Iranian languages known as [[Scythian languages|Scythian]]. The Scythian group included numerous tribes, known in ancient sources as the [[Scythians]], [[Massagetae]], [[Saka]], [[Sarmatians]], [[Alans]] and [[Roxolans]]. The more easterly [[Khwarezm|Khorezmians]] and the [[Sogdians]] were also closely affiliated, in linguistic terms. Ossetian, together with [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Tati (Iran)|Tati]] and [[Talysh language|Talyshi]], is one of the main [[Iranian languages]] with a sizable community of speakers in the Caucasus. It is descended from [[Alanic language|Alanic]], the language of the [[Alans]], medieval tribes emerging from the earlier [[Sarmatians]]. It is believed to be the only surviving descendant of a [[Scythian languages|Sarmatian language]]. The closest genetically related language may be the [[Yaghnobi language]] of [[Tajikistan]], the only other living Northeastern Iranian language.Abaev, V. I. ''A Grammatical Sketch of Ossetian.'' Translated by Stephen P. Hill and edited by Herbert H. Paper, 1964 [http://www.azargoshnasp.net/languages/ossetian/ossetian.htm]Thordarson, Fridrik. 1989. ''Ossetic.'' Compendium Linguarum Iranicarum, ed. by Rudiger Schmitt, 456-479. Wiesbaden: Reichert. [http://www.azargoshnasp.net/languages/ossetian/ossetian.htm] Ossetian has a plural formed by the suffix -''ta'', a feature it shares with Yaghnobi, Sarmatian and the now-extinct Sogdian; this is taken as evidence of a formerly wide-ranging Iranian-language [[dialect continuum]] on the [[Central Asia]]n [[steppe]]. The names of ancient Iranian tribes (as transmitted through Ancient Greek) in fact reflect this pluralization, e.g. ''Saromatae'' (Σαρομάται) and ''Masagetae'' (Μασαγέται).{{cite journal |last1=Kim |first1=Ronald |title=On the Historical Phonology of Ossetic: The Origin of the Oblique Case Suffix |journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society |date=2003 |volume=123 |issue=1 |pages=43–72 |doi=10.2307/3217844}}{{rp|69}} ===Evidence for Medieval Ossetian=== The earliest known written sample of Ossetian is an [[inscription]] which dates from the 10th to 12th centuries and was found near the River [[Bolshoi Zelenchuk]] at [[Arkhyz]]. The text is written in the [[Greek alphabet]], with special [[Digraph (orthography)|digraphs]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Inscription !! Transliteration !! Translation |- | —ΣΑΧΗΡΗ ΦΟΥΡΤ ΧΟΒΣ
ΗΣΤΟΡΗ ΦΟΥΡΤ ΠΑΚΑΘΑΡ
ΠΑΚΑΘΑΡΗ ΦΟΥΡΤ ΑΝΠΑΛΑΝ
ΑΝΠΑΛΑΝΗ ΦΟΥΡΤ ΛΑΚ
ΑΝΗ ΤΖΗΡΘΕ || —''Saxiri Furt Xovs
Istori Furt Bæqætar
Bæqætari Furt Æmbalan
Æmbalani Furt Lak
Ani čirtī'' || "K., son of S., son of I., son of B., son of A.; [this is] their monument."{{rp|55–56}} The original, following Zgusta, translates only initials; presumably this is because although the uninflected forms may be inferred, no written records of them have been found to date. |} The only other extant record of Proto-Ossetic are the two lines of "Alanic" phrases appearing in the ''Theogony'' of [[John Tzetzes]], a 12th century [[Byzantine]] [[poet]] and [[philologist|grammarian]]: {{quote|{{lang|grc|Τοῖς ἀλανοῖς προσφθέγγομαι κατά τήν τούτων γλῶσσαν
Καλή ημέρα σου αὐθεντα μου αρχόντισσα πόθεν εἶσαι
''Ταπαγχὰς μέσφιλι χσινὰ κορθὶ κάντα'' καὶ τ’άλλα
ἂν ὃ ἒχη ἀλάνισσα παπὰν φίλον ἀκούσαις ταῦτα
οὐκ αἰσχύνεσσι αὐθέντρια μου νὰ μου γαμὴ τὸ μουνί σου παπᾶς
''τὸ φάρνετζ κίντζι μέσφιλι καίτζ φουὰ σαοῦγγε''|italic=unset}}{{rp|54}}{{sfn|Zgusta|1987}}}} The italicized portions above are Ossetian. Going beyond a direct transliteration of the Greek text, scholars have attempted a [[phonology|phonological]] [[Internal reconstruction|reconstruction]] using the Greek as clues, thus, while τ ([[tau]]) would usually be given the value "t," it instead is "d", which is thought to be the way the early Ossetes would have pronounced it. The scholarly transliteration of the Alanic phrases is: "dæ ban xʷærz, mæ sfili, (æ)xsinjæ kurθi kændæ" and "du farnitz, kintzæ mæ sfili, kajci fæ wa sawgin?"; equivalents in modern Ossetian would be ''"Dæ bon xwarz, me’fšini ‘xšinæ, kurdigæj dæ?"'' and ''"(De’) f(s)arm neč(ij), kinźi æfšini xæcc(æ) (ku) fæwwa sawgin"''.{{cite conference |first=Tamerlan |last=Kambolov |title=Some New Observations on the Zelenchuk Inscription and Tzetzes’ Alanic Phrases |conference=Scythians, Sarmatians, Alans – Iranian-Speaking Nomads of the Eurasian Steppes |pages=21–22 |location=Barcelona |date=10 May 2007 |url=http://class.csueastbay.edu/anthropologymuseum/2006IA/DNA_PDFS/yDNA/Sarmatian%20Abstracts.pdf |access-date=2 February 2015}} The passage translates as: {{quote|The Alans I greet in their language:
"Good day to you my lord's lady, where are you from?"
"Good day to you my lord's lady, where are you from?" and other things:
When an Alan woman takes a priest as a lover, you might hear this:
"Aren't you ashamed, my lordly lady, that your cunt is being fucked by a priest?"
"Aren't you ashamed, my lady, to have a love affair with the priest?"{{sfn|Zgusta|1987}}}} [[Marginalia]] of Greek religious books, with some parts (such as headlines) of the book translated into Old Ossetic, have been recently found.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} It is theorized that during the Proto-Ossetic phase, Ossetian underwent a process of phonological change conditioned by a ''[[Rhythmusgesetz]]'' or "Rhythm-law" whereby nouns were divided into two classes, those heavily or lightly [[Stress (linguistics)|stressed]]. "Heavy-stem" nouns possessed a "heavy" long [[vowel]] or [[diphthong]], and were stressed on the first-occurring syllable of this type; "light-stem" nouns were stressed on their final syllable. This is precisely the situation observed in the earliest (though admittedly scanty) records of Ossetian presented above.{{rp|47}} This situation also obtains in Modern Ossetian, although the emphasis in [[Digor dialect|Digor]] is also affected by the "openness" of the vowel.{{sfn|Zgusta|1987|p=51}} The trend is also found in a [[glossary]] of the [[Jassic dialect]] dating from 1422.{{sfn|Zgusta|1987|p=55}} ==Dialects== There are two important dialects: [[Iron dialect|Iron]] and [[Digor dialect|Digor]], spoken by five-sixths and one-sixth of the population, respectively. A third dialect of Ossetian, [[Jassic dialect|Jassic]], was formerly spoken in [[Hungary]]. ==Phonology== {{Listen |filename = |title = Example of the speech |description = The [[Lord's Prayer]] in Ossetic (Irian dialect). |format = [[Ogg]]}} The Iron dialect of Ossetic has 7 vowels: {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="text-align: center" |- ! !! [[Front vowel|Front]] !! [[Central vowel|Central]] !! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{lang|os|и}} {{IPA|/i/}} || || {{lang|os|у}} {{IPA|/u/}} |- ! [[Close-mid vowel|Close-mid]] | || {{lang|os|ы}} {{IPA|/ɪ̈/}} || |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{lang|os|е}} {{IPA|/e/}} || || {{lang|os|о}} {{IPA|/o/}} |- ! [[Near-open vowel|Near-open]] | || {{lang|os|ӕ}} {{IPA|/ə/}} || |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | || {{lang|os|а}} {{IPA|/a/}} || |} Ossetian researcher [[Vasily Abayev|V. I. Abayev]] distinguishes 26 consonants, to which five labialized consonants and two semivowels may be added. Unusually for an Indo-European language, there is a series of [[Glottalization|glottalized]] ([[Ejective consonant|ejective]]) stops and affricates. Stress normally falls on the first syllable, unless it has a "weak" vowel ({{IPA|/ɪ̈/}} or {{IPA|/ə/}}), in which case it falls on the second syllable. In the Iron dialect, definiteness is expressed in post-initially stressed words by shifting the stress to the initial syllable. This reflects the fact that historically they received a [[syllable|syllabic]] [[definite article]] (as they still do in the Digor dialect), and the addition of the syllable caused the stress to shift. ==Grammar== According to [[Vasily Abaev|V.I. Abaev]], {{bq|In the course of centuries-long propinquity to and intercourse with Caucasian languages, Ossetian became similar to them in some features, particularly in phonetics and lexicon. However, it retained its grammatical structure and basic lexical stock; its relationship with the Iranian family, despite considerable individual traits, does not arouse any doubt.}} ===Nouns=== Ossetic has lost the grammatical category of [[grammatical gender|gender]] which many Indo-European languages have preserved until today. According to the Encyclopædia Britannica 2006Ossetic language. (2006). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved August 26, 2006, from Encyclopædia Britannica Premium Service: http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9057571 Ossetian preserves many archaic features of Old Iranian, such as eight cases and verbal prefixes. It is debated how many of these cases are actually inherited from Indo-Iranian case morphemes and how many have re-developed, after the loss of the original case forms, through [[clitic]]ization of adverbs or re-interpretations of [[Derivation (linguistics)|derivational suffixes]]: the number of "inherited" cases according to different scholars ranges from as few as three (nominative, genitive and inessive) to as many as six (nominative, dative, ablative, directive, inessive). Some (the comitative, equative, and adessive) are secondary beyond any doubt.Т.Т. Камболов. 2006 Очерк истории осетинского языка. p.330-339 ====Definiteness==== [[Definiteness]] is, according to Abaev, only expressed by shift of word accent from the second to the first syllable (which is not possible in all nouns): * ''færǽt'' "an axe" * ''fǽræt'' "the axe" ====Cases==== Nouns and adjectives share the same morphology and distinguish two numbers (singular and plural) and nine cases: [[nominative]], [[genitive]], [[dative]], directive, [[ablative]], [[inessive]], [[adessive]], [[Equative case|equative]], and [[comitative]]. The nominal morphology is [[agglutinative]]: the case suffixes and the number suffix are separate, the case suffixes are the same for both numbers and the number suffix is the same for all cases: {| class="wikitable" ! width=100 | ! width=100 |Singular ! width=100 |Plural |- ! Nominative | align=center |сӕр ''sær'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ӕ ''sær'''t'''æ'' |- ! Genitive | align=center |сӕры ''særy'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ы ''sær'''t'''y'' |- ! Dative | align=center |сӕрӕн ''særæn'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ӕн ''sær'''t'''æn'' |- ! Allative | align=center |сӕрмӕ ''særmæ'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ӕм ''sær'''t'''æm'' |- ! Ablative | align=center |сӕрӕй ''særæj'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ӕй ''sær'''t'''æj'' |- ! Inessive | align=center |сӕры ''særy'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ы ''sær'''t'''y'' |- ! Adessive | align=center |сӕрыл ''særyl'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ыл ''sær'''t'''yl'' |- ! Equative | align=center |сӕрау ''særau'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''ау ''sær'''t'''au'' |- ! Comitative | align=center |сӕримӕ ''særimæ'' | align=center |сӕр'''т'''имӕ ''sær'''t'''imæ'' |} Since inessive and genitive show the same forms in both numbers, it is sometimes debated whether Ossetian might possess eight case forms for each number instead of nine. ===Verbs=== Verbs distinguish six persons (1st, 2nd and 3d, singular and plural), three tenses (present, past and future, all expressed [[synthetic language|synthetically]]), and three moods ([[indicative]], [[subjunctive]], [[Imperative mood|imperative]]). The person, tense and mood morphemes are mostly fused. [[Passive voice]] is expressed [[periphrastic]]ally with the past passive participle and an [[auxiliary verb]] meaning "to go"; causative and reflexive meaning are also expressed by periphrastic constructions. Verbs may belong to one of two [[lexical aspect]]s ([[perfective]] vs [[imperfective]]); these are expressed by prefixes, which often have prepositional origin. There is an [[infinitive]] (morphologically coinciding with the 1st person singular, but syntactically forming a [[nominal phrase]]), four participles (present and past active, past passive, and future), and a [[gerund]]. Vowel and consonant alternations occur between the present and past stems of the verb and between intransitive and transitive forms. Intransitive and transitive verbs also differ in the endings they take in the past tense (in intransitive verbs, the construction is, in origin, a periphrastic combination of the past passive participle and the verb "to be"). There are also special verb forms, such as immediate future tense that is transmitted by adding -inag to the verb and the auxiliary verb meaning "to be". Future Imperative is another special form that is transmitted through usage of independent particle iu. Yet another special verbal form that is used to reflect either an interrupted process or a process that has nearly been completed. This form is made up through the use of a particle sæi that is stuck between the prefix, usually fæ- and the verb. Ossetic uses mostly [[postposition]]s (derived from nouns), although two prepositions exist in the language. [[modifier (grammar)|Noun modifier]]s precede nouns. The [[word order]] is not rigid, but tends towards [[Subject–object–verb|SOV]]. The [[morphosyntactic alignment]] is [[nominative–accusative]], although there is no [[accusative case]]: rather, the direct object is in the nominative (typically if [[animacy|inanimate]] or [[definiteness|indefinite]]) or in the genitive (typically if animate or definite). For numerals above 20, two systems are in use – a [[decimal]] one used officially, and a [[vigesimal]] one used colloquially. ==Writing system== [[File:Oseta kartvela skribo.jpg|225px|thumb|right|Ossetic text written with Georgian script, from a book on Ossetian folklore published in 1940 in South Ossetia]] Written Ossetian may be immediately recognized by its use of the [[Ae (Cyrillic)|Cyrillic letter Ae]] (Ӕ ӕ), a letter to be found in no other language using [[Cyrillic script]]. The father of the modern Ossetian literary language is the national poet [[Kosta Khetagurov]] (1859–1906). An Iron literary language was established in the 18th century, written using the Cyrillic script in Russia and the Georgian script in Georgia. The first Ossetian book was published in Cyrillic in 1798, and in 1844 the alphabet was revised by a Russian scientist of Finnish-Swedish origin, [[Anders Johan Sjögren|Andreas Sjögren]]. A new alphabet based on the [[Latin script]] was made official in the 1920s, but in 1937 a revised Cyrillic alphabet was introduced, with digraphs replacing most [[diacritic]]s of the 1844 alphabet. In 1820, I. Yalguzidze published a Georgian-script alphabetic primer, adding three letters to the Georgian alphabet.[http://ironau.ru/kaos.html Correspondence table between the Georgian based and the modern script with examples of use] {{ref-ru}} The Georgian orthography receded in the 19th century, but was made official with Georgian autonomy in 1937. The "one nation – two alphabets" issue caused discontent in South Ossetia in the year 1951 demanding reunification of the script, and in 1954 Georgian was replaced with the 1937 Cyrillic alphabet. A Digor literary language was established in the late 19th century, using the Arabic script. It was abolished in 1939, five years before the Digor were deported to Siberia. Iron in Cyrillic is now the literary language for both dialects. The "weak" vowels {{angle bracket|æ}} {{IPA|[ə]}} and {{angle bracket|ы}} {{IPA|[ɪ̈]}} are extremely common in the language. ==Language usage== [[File:1agRastdzinad.jpg|thumb|225px|The first page of the first issue of the Ossetian newspaper ''[[Ræstdzinad]]''. Sjögren's Cyrillic alphabet. 1923]] The first printed book in Ossetian appeared in 1798. The first newspaper, ''[[Iron Gazet]]'', appeared on July 23, 1906 in [[Vladikavkaz]]. While Ossetian is the official language in both South and North Ossetia (along with Russian), its official use is limited to publishing new laws in Ossetian newspapers. There are two daily newspapers in Ossetian: ''[[Ræstdzinad]]'' (Рæстдзинад / Рӕстꚉінад, "Truth") in the North and ''[[Xurzærin]]'' (Хурзæрин, "The Sun") in the South. Some smaller newspapers, such as district newspapers, use Ossetian for some articles. There is a monthly magazine ''[[Max dug]]'' (Мах дуг, "Our era"), mostly devoted to contemporary Ossetian fiction and poetry. Ossetian is taught in secondary schools for all pupils.{{cn|date=December 2016}} Native Ossetian speakers also take courses in [[Ossetian literature]]. The first Ossetian language Bible was published in 2010.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/oss|title=Ossetic|newspaper=Ethnologue|access-date=2017-01-08}} It is currently the only full version of the Bible in the Ossetian language.{{Cite news|url=https://www.jw.org/en/news/legal/by-region/russia/censorship-russian-bibles-literature/#?insight%5Bsearch_id%5D=8a185b64-5401-456c-a423-e5f8ddaa7936&insight%5Bsearch_result_index%5D=0|title=Russian Censorship: Ossetian & Russian Bibles, Bible Literature|newspaper=JW.ORG|access-date=2017-01-08}} ==Vocabulary== The following table illustrates some common Ossetic words with cognates or translations in other [[Indo-Iranian languages|Indo-Iranian]] and other Indo-European languages. {|border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" class="wikitable" |+Translations into different languages !
